SlimUdpSocket Class Reference

SlimUdpSocket is a class to encapsulate a UDP socket to send and receive datagrams. More...

Detailed Description

SlimUdpSocket is a class to encapsulate a UDP socket to send and receive datagrams.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

SlimUdpSocket::SlimUdpSocket (  void   ) 
 

Construct a new SlimUdpSocket object. To be able to send and recieve data, the socket must be opened via open(int port)

See also:
open(int port)

SlimUdpSocket::SlimUdpSocket (  int  port  ) 
 

Construct a new SlimUdpSocket object, pre-configured to work on port port To be able to send and recieve data, the socket must be opened via open() or open(int port)

Member Function Documentation

int SlimUdpSocket::open (  int  port  ) 
 

Initialize and open the socket on a port specified by port

Returns:
0 (SLIMSOCKET_NOERROR) if no error occurs, an error code else
See also:
SlimUdpSocket()

Initialize and open the socket on a port specified while calling constructor SlimUdpSocket(int port)

Returns:

int SlimUdpSocket::sendData (  const char *  ip,
int  port,
const char *  buffer,
int  nbByteToSend
) 
 

Send nbByteToSend of buffer to the location specified with ip and port

Parameters:
ip contains a string that represent an ip address. Ex: A valid value for ip could be "129.88.46.229".
port contains the targeted port
buffer is a reference to the buffer where are located data to send
nbByteToSend contains the number of bytes of buffer to send
Returns:
0 (SLIMSOCKET_NOERROR) if no error occurs, an error code else

int SlimUdpSocket::sendData (  const char *  buffer,
int  nbByteToSend
) 
 

Send nbByteToSend of buffer to the location previously defined by a call to setRecipientAddress() or sendData(char *ip, int port, char *buffer, int nbByteToSend).

Parameters:
buffer is a reference to the buffer where are located data to send
nbByteToSend contains the number of bytes of buffer to send
Returns:

int SlimUdpSocket::waitingForData (  char *  buffer  ) 
 

Wait for incoming data

Parameters:
buffer is a reference to a buffer where recieved data could be store. It must be big enough to host incoming data.
Returns:
the number of bytes received and stored in buffer
